title: A Practical Approach to Power Saving in Hearables Using Sub-Nyquist Sampling with Bandwidth Extension
author: Tarikul Islam Tamiti (George Mason University), Anomadarshi Barua (George Mason University), ...
relevance_why: This work significantly explores audio processing techniques that could enhance Haohe Liu's research in audio quality restoration and low-power audio applications, particularly relevant for speech enhancement tasks.
background: The study focuses on enhancing speech quality through low-power methods in hearable devices by leveraging sub-Nyquist sampling and bandwidth extension techniques.
contribution: This paper introduces SUBARU (Sub-Nyquist Audio Resolution Upsampling) to solve the low power consumption in hearables, achieving a 3.31x reduction in power while maintaining audio quality.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods of speech enhancement often rely on high-resolution audio processing, resulting in high power consumption and limited real-time applicability.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work improves by implementing a sub-Nyquist sampling strategy combined with unique virtual discriminator techniques, achieving comparable audio quality without the complexity of GANs.

key_innovation: The paper uniquely blends sub-Nyquist sampling with neural network architectures, enabling efficient audio processing with decreased power consumption while maintaining sound quality.
real_world_impact: This innovation can substantially extend battery life in wearable devices, enhancing user experience in noisy environments, which is increasingly relevant in modern smart technology applications.
limitations: No limitations were explicitly mentioned by the authors.

new_terms.sub-Nyquist sampling: **Sub-Nyquist sampling** refers to the process of sampling a signal at a rate lower than the Nyquist rate, which is twice the highest frequency in the signal, allowing for reduced power usage.
new_terms.virtual discriminators: **Virtual discriminators** are loss functions that mimic the behavior of generative adversarial networks' discriminators without the computational and resource demands of full GAN implementations.
